criteria: Explanation of Natural Selection and Trait Distribution
Understanding of Cause and Effect Relationships
descriptions: No attempt to use mathematical representations.
Uses mathematical representations, but they are inaccurate or irrelevant to the explanation.
Uses basic mathematical representations with limited connection to the explanation of trait changes.
Uses mathematical representations to support the explanation of trait changes, but with some inaccuracies or omissions.
Effectively uses mathematical representations, including probability and proportional reasoning, to support explanations of trends in trait changes within populations over time. Shows minor errors.

Masterfully uses mathematical representations, including probability and proportional reasoning, to provide clear, accurate, and thorough explanations of trends in trait changes within populations over time.
No explanation of natural selection or trait distribution is provided.
Provides a vague or inaccurate description of natural selection and its effect on trait distribution.
Describes natural selection and trait distribution, but lacks depth or connection to mathematical representations.
Explains how natural selection may lead to increases and decreases of specific traits in populations, but the explanation is incomplete or contains minor inaccuracies.

Clearly explains how natural selection leads to changes in the distribution of traits in a population over time, connecting it to environmental conditions and mathematical representations. Shows minor errors.

Provides a comprehensive and insightful explanation of how natural selection drives changes in trait distribution, thoroughly integrating mathematical representations and demonstrating a deep understanding of adaptation.
Demonstrates no understanding of cause-and-effect relationships in the context of natural selection.
Identifies cause-and-effect relationships, but the explanation is unclear or inaccurate.
Describes cause-and-effect relationships in natural selection, but lacks specific examples or mathematical support.
Explains cause-and-effect relationships related to how environmental changes influence trait prevalence with some omissions.
Clearly explains cause-and-effect relationships between environmental factors, natural selection, and changes in trait distribution, supported by mathematical reasoning.

Provides a sophisticated analysis of cause-and-effect relationships, including the role of probability, to explain complex patterns of trait distribution within populations, thoroughly integrating mathematical support.
